ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: Magnetoelectric effect in bilayer magnetostrictive-piezoelectric structure. Theory and experiment

Affiliation.OrgName: Institute of Technical Acoustics NAS of Belarus

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para: Bilayer magnetostrictive-piezoelectric structures have certain advantages compared to bulk composites and this allows us to consider them as perspective materials for the development of devices based on the magnetoelectric effect. The theory of magnetoelectric effect in bilayer magnetostrictive-piezoelectric structure is presented taking into account the thickness dependence amplitude of the mechanical oscillations for the structures in form of rectangular plate. The equation for frequency dependence of the ME effect in the region on the electromechanical resonance was obtained, using motion equation, elastodynamics and electrostatic equations for the magnetostrictive, piezoelectric phases and taking into account the boundary conditions on the interface. The cases of longitudinal and transverse orientations of the electric and magnetic fields were considered. It is shown that the thickness dependence of the ME voltage coefficient has the maximum. The dependence between frequency and the thickness ratio of the layers is presented for both the theory and experiment.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para: Ferrite-piezoelectric structures cause a great interest because in these structures there are effects which can be absent in ferrite and piezoelectric components separately. These effects appear due to mechanical interaction between the magnetostrictive and piezoelectric subsystems. Magnetoelectric (ME) effect is one of such effects, which is caused by the elastic interaction of magnetostrictive and piezoelectric subsystems in bilayer structures. The action of the magnetic field in the magnetostrictive phase induces mechanical deformations which pass via mechanical coupling into the piezoelectric phase and lead to the change of the polarization of the sample. The frequency dependence of the effect is defined by the dispersion relation for such type of waves, because ME effect in composites is caused by the elastic interaction of magnetostrictive and piezoelectric phases. The advantage of bilayer magnetostrictive-piezoelectric structure is that the value of ME effect in such samples is greater than in bulk composites [1]. The theory of the ME effect in bulk and multilayer composites has been developed in the region of electromechanical resonance [2–4]. In these papers, an expression for ME voltage coefficient was defined by the method of effective parameters and the frequency dependence was analyzed. One of the disadvantages of the method of effective parameters is its usage limitation. The method is applicable when the characteristic size of the structural units of the composite is much smaller than the length of the acoustic oscillations, so that the composite can be considered as a homogeneous medium. The ME effect in bilayer structure was considered earlier based on the simultaneous solution of motion and material equations for the magnetostrictive and piezoelectric phases [5–9]. However, it was suggested in these papers that the amplitude of the oscillations is the same over the thickness of each, magnetic and piezoelectric, components. This suggestion can be used in the description of the effect for rather thin layers, with some accuracy. The ME effect was considered for a structure, representing a thin film grown on a semi-infinite substrate, taking into account the changes of the amplitude in oscillations over the thickness of the sample [10]. At the same time, in practice we often meet structures presenting mechanically interacting magnetostrictive and piezoelectric layers of finite thickness. In this paper, the consistent theory of ME effect is presented in such structures. The propagation of elastic waves is considered in bilayer magnetostrictive-piezoelectric structure and the expression for the ME voltage coefficient is obtained given that the amplitude of the oscillations is changed over the thickness of the sample. Under the limiting transition, it is shown that in case of thin layers the expressions for the dispersion relation of elastic oscillations and the ME coefficient passes to the same expressions given earlier [5–9]. The dependence of the resonance frequency on thickness is investigated and the results are presented for the theory and experiment.

Section1.Heading: Model and basic equations
Section1.Para:
As a model, we consider a bilayer structure in the form of a rectangular plate of length L and width W, consisting of mechanically interacting magnetostrictive and piezoelectric layers of thickness m
t and p
t, the values which are not assumed to be small (Fig. 1). Thin metal contacts are applied on the top and the bottom of the plate.
Fig. 1
Schematic view of the sample: 1—Magnetostrictive phase, 2—Piezoelectric phase, 3—Electrodes

Let us consider that the origin of the coordinates coincides with the boundary of the partition of magnetostrictive and piezoelectric layers. The direction Z is perpendicular to that boundary. Preliminarily, the piezoelectric layer is polarized perpendicularly to the contact (Z axis). The alternating magnetic field with frequency ω causes elastic oscillations in the magnetostrictive component, transferring through the interface of the partition to the piezoelectric component through the shear stresses, which brings to interconnected oscillations of magnetostrictive and piezoelectric subsystems. As there is a nonuniformity along Z axis and the width of the plate is small (Y axis), under the first approximation we can assume that the displacements along plane Y are homogeneous and the nonzero components of stress are only α
T
xx and α
T
xz . The value of the stresses will depend on the thickness of the sample, perpendicularly to the interface between magnetostrictive and piezoelectric phases. Therefore the equations of motion for the x projection of the α
u
x displacement vector for the magnetostrictive and piezoelectric phases are of the form 1
$$ {}^{\alpha}\rho \frac{\partial^{2}{}^{\alpha} u_{x}}{\partial t^{2}} = \frac{\partial {}^{\alpha} T_{xx}}{\partial x} + \frac{\partial {}^{\alpha} T_{xz}}{\partial z}, $$ where upper-case index “α” is correspondingly “m” for ferrite and “p” for piezoelectric, α
ρ is the density of ferrite and piezoelectric layers, α
T
ij are the components of the stress tensor.

The constitutive equations for the magnetostrictive and piezoelectric phases are 2
$$\begin{aligned} &{{}^{p}S_{i} = {}^{p}s_{ij}{}^{p}T_{j} + {}^{p}d_{ki}{}^{p}E_{k},} \end{aligned}$$
3
$$\begin{aligned} &{{}^{p}D_{k} = {}^{p} \varepsilon_{kn}{}^{p}E_{n} + {}^{p}d_{ki}{}^{p}T_{i},} \end{aligned}$$
4
$$\begin{aligned} &{{}^{m}S_{i} = {}^{m}s_{ij}{}^{m}T_{j} + {}^{m}q_{ki}{}^{m}H_{k},} \end{aligned}$$
5
$$\begin{aligned} &{{}^{m}B_{k} = {}^{m}q_{ki}{}^{m}T_{i} + {}^{m}\mu_{kn}{}^{m}H_{n},} \end{aligned}$$ where p
S
i and m
S
i are the strain tensor components of the piezoelectric and magnetostrictive phases; p
E
k and m
H
k are the vector components of the electric and magnetic fields; p
D
k and m
B
k are the vector components of the electric displacement and the magnetic induction; p
T
i and m
T
i are the stress tensor components of the piezoelectric and the magnetostrictive phases; p
s
ij and m
s
ij are the compliance coefficients of the piezoelectric and magnetostrictive phases; p
d
ki and m
q
ki are the piezoelectric and piezomagnetic coefficients; and p
ε
kn and m
μ
kn are the tensor components of permittivity and permeability.

A dc (bias) and an ac magnetic field can be directed either along the Z axis normal to the contact plane or the contact plane (X axis). Therefore, we will consider the cases of longitudinal and transverse orientation of the fields.

Section1.Heading: Dispersion relation
Section1.Para:
Taking into account nonuniformity along the Z axis, the solution of equation for the displacement vector of the medium will be presented as planar waves, whose amplitudes are changed on the thickness of the sample and have the following form: 6
$$ ^{\alpha} u(x,z) = {}^{\alpha} g(z) \bigl({}^{\alpha} A\cos ( \omega {t} - kx) + {}^{\alpha} B\sin (\omega {t} - kx)\bigr), $$ where α
A and α
B are the constants of integration and α
g(z) are some functions.

The substitution of this expression into the expression for the motion of the medium gives the equation for function α
g(z). Solution of this equation depends on the ration of elastic wave velocity in ferrite and piezoelectric phases. For the sake of definiteness we choose a structure of ferrite and piezoelectric, in which the velocity of elastic waves in the ferrite will be higher than that in the piezoelectric phase. Particularly, these conditions are true for structures nickel–lead zirconate titanate (Ni-PZT). The boundary conditions, namely, the normal components of stress tensor on top and bottom surfaces, are zero and the displacement of ferrite and piezoelectric media on interface are equal, as equal are the shear stresses. These boundary conditions determine a system of equations. Solution of these equations gives the dispersion relation in the following form: 7
$$ {}^{m}Y{}^{m}\chi th\bigl({}^{m}\kappa \bigr) = {}^{p}Y{}^{p}\chi tg\bigl({}^{p}\kappa \bigr), $$ where α
κ= α
χ
α
t is a non-dimensional parameter, α
t is the thickness of the piezoelectric and magnetostrictive phases,
$$\begin{aligned} &{{}^{m}\chi^{2} = - 2(1 + \nu )\biggl[ \frac{\omega^{2}}{{}^{m}V^{2}_{L}} - k^{2} \biggr],} \\ &{{}^{p}\chi^{2} = 2(1 + \nu ) \biggl[ \frac{\omega^{2}}{{}^{p}V^{2}_{L}} - k^{2} \biggr],} \\ &{\frac{1}{{}^{m}V_{L}^{2}} = \frac{{}^{m}\rho}{{}^{m}Y}, \qquad \frac{1}{{}^{p}V_{L}^{2}} = \frac{{}^{p}\rho}{{}^{p}Y};} \end{aligned}$$
m
V
L and p
V
L are the velocities of longitudinal waves respectively in the magnetostrictive and piezoelectric medium;
${}^{m}Y = \frac{1}{{}^{m}s_{xx}}$ and
${}^{p}Y = \frac{1}{{}^{p}s_{xx}}$ are the Young’s moduli of magnetostrictive and piezoelectric phases, respectively, and ν is the Poisson’s ratio.
Equation (7) defines the dependence of frequency ω on the wave vector k in an implicit form for the propagation of elastic waves in bilayer magnetostrictive-piezoelectric structures.

The approximate expression for the dispersion relation of thin magnetostrictive and piezoelectric phases when m
κ= m
χ
m
t≪1 and p
κ= p
χ
p
t≪1 is obtained in the following form: 8
$$ {}^{m}Y \cdot \bigl({}^{m}\chi \bigr)^{2} \cdot {}^{m}t = {}^{p}Y \cdot \bigl({}^{p}\chi \bigr)^{2} \cdot {}^{p}t. $$

Taking into account the expressions for m
χ, p
χ and Eq. (8), after simple transformations, the dispersion relation is obtained in the following form: 9
$$ \omega = \sqrt{\frac{{}^{m}Y \cdot {}^{m}t + {}^{p}Y \cdot {}^{p}t}{{}^{m}\rho \cdot {}^{m}t + {}^{p}\rho \cdot {}^{p}t}} \cdot k. $$
This expression for dispersion relation coincides with the expression previously obtained [8].

Section1.Heading: Longitudinal orientation of the electric and magnetic fields
Section1.Para: In the case of longitudinal fields the magnetic fields (constant H 0 and alternating H with the frequency ω) coincide in direction with the polarization vector P. We restrict our consideration to the planar vibrations propagating along the plate (axis X). The alternating magnetic field induces longitudinal vibrations in the magnetostrictive phase due to magnetostriction that is transferred via the mechanical contact into the piezoelectric phase, where the electric field is induced due to piezoelectric effect.

The equations for the strain tensors of the piezoelectric and magnetostrictive layers p
S
i , m
S
i and the Z axis projection of the electric displacement p
D
z can be written in the following form: 10
$$\begin{aligned} &{{}^{p}S_{xx} = \frac{1}{{}^{p}Y}{}^{p}T_{xx} + {}^{p}d_{xx,z}{}^{p}E_{z},} \end{aligned}$$
11
$$\begin{aligned} &{{}^{p}S_{xz} = \frac{1}{{}^{p}G}{}^{p}T_{xz},} \end{aligned}$$
12
$$\begin{aligned} &{{}^{p}D_{z} = {}^{p} \varepsilon_{zz}{}^{p}E_{z} + {}^{p}d_{xx,z}{}^{p}T_{xx},} \end{aligned}$$
13
$$\begin{aligned} &{{}^{m}S_{xx} = \frac{1}{{}^{m}Y}{}^{m}T_{xx} + {}^{m}q_{xx,z}{}^{m}H_{z},} \end{aligned}$$
14
$$\begin{aligned} &{{}^{m}S_{xz} = \frac{1}{{}^{m}G}{}^{m}T_{xz},} \end{aligned}$$ where
${}^{p}G = \frac{1}{{}^{p}s_{xz}}$ and
${}^{m}G = \frac{1}{{}^{m}s_{xz}}$ are the shear modulus of the piezoelectric and magnetostrictive phases, respectively.

ME voltage coefficient is defined as the ratio of arising electric field E to the magnetic field which induced it, i.e.: 15
$$ \alpha_{E} = E/H. $$

However, in contrast to bulk composites, ME voltage coefficient can be defined in two ways for layered magnetostrictive-piezoelectric structures. The first method of determining the ME voltage coefficient is to define it as the ratio of the electric field produced into the piezoelectric to the magnetic field into the magnetostrictive phase. With this definition the ME coefficient well characterizes the efficiency of ME transformation of the fields; however, under this definition, the ME coefficient is not well characterizing the efficiency of ME transformation of the structure. Moreover, the definition of ME voltage coefficient leads to a nonphysical result which is that the ME coefficient has a finite value in the limiting transition, when the thickness of piezoelectric phase converges to zero. The second method of determining the ME voltage coefficient is to define it as the ratio of the average value of the electric field to the average value of the external magnetic field. Then: 16
$$ \langle \alpha_{E} \rangle = \langle E \rangle /H, $$ where 〈E〉=U/( m
t+ p
t) is the average value of the electric field of the structure, U is the potential difference between the electrodes. With the second method of determination, the ME voltage coefficient characterizes the efficiency of ME transformation of the entire structure and has a maximum value at a certain ratio of the thickness of the magnetostrictive and piezoelectric layers.

In order to define a theoretical expression for the ME voltage coefficient, we use the method developed earlier [2–4]. The condition of mechanical equilibrium at the free surfaces of the plate, i.e. points x=∓L/2, gives boundary conditions in the form 17
$$ \int_{ - {}^{p}t}^{0} {}^{p}T_{xx}( \pm L/2,z)\,dz + \int_{0}^{{}^{m}t} {}^{m}T_{xx} ( \pm L/2)\,dz = 0. $$ Using Eq. (17) we can find the constants of integration A and B in expression (6) for displacement vector of the medium.

We will find the ME voltage coefficient using the open circuit condition I=0, where the electric current is determined by the expression 18
$$ I = \int_{0}^{W} dy\int_{ - L/2}^{L/2} {}^{p}D_{z}\,dx. $$

Expressing the stress tensor component p
T
xx by the strain tensor component p
S
xx from Eq. (10) and substituting them into Eq. (12), we obtain the expression for the electric displacement p
D
z . Then, substituting the expression obtained for p
D
z into Eq. (18) and using the condition of open circuit I=0, we obtain the equation for the electric field 〈E〉 taking into account Eqs. (6) and (17). Thus, we find the ME voltage coefficient using Eq. (16) and the fact that the potential difference between the electrodes is defined as U=〈 p
E
z 〉 p
t. Finally, in the case of longitudinal orientation of the fields, we obtain the expression for the ME voltage coefficient in the form: 19
$$\begin{aligned} \alpha_{E,L} =& \frac{{}^{p}Y{}^{p}d_{xx,z}{}^{m}q_{xx,z}}{{}^{p}\varepsilon_{zz}\varDelta _{L}} \frac{{}^{m}Y{}^{m}t}{{}^{m}Y{}^{m}t\frac{th({}^{m}\kappa )}{{}^{m}\kappa} + {}^{p}Y{}^{p}t\frac{tg({}^{p}\kappa )}{{}^{p}\kappa}} \\ & {}\times \frac{tg(\kappa )}{\kappa} \frac{tg({}^{p}\kappa )}{{}^{p}\kappa} \frac{{}^{p}t}{({}^{m}t + {}^{p}t)}, \end{aligned}$$ where
$$\begin{aligned} \varDelta _{L} = &1 - K_{p}^{2} \biggl( 1 - \frac{{}^{p}Y{}^{p}t}{{}^{m}Y{}^{m}t\frac{th({}^{m}\kappa )}{{}^{m}\kappa} + {}^{p}Y{}^{p}t\frac{tg({}^{p}\kappa )}{{}^{p}\kappa}} \\ &{}\times\frac{tg(\kappa )}{\kappa} \frac{tg({}^{p}\kappa )}{{}^{p}\kappa} \biggr), \end{aligned}$$ with
$K_{p}^{2} = \frac{{}^{p}Y({}^{p}d_{xx,z})^{2}}{{}^{p}\varepsilon_{zz}}$ the squared coefficient of electromechanical coupling and κ=kL/2 the dimensionless parameter.

Section1.Heading: Transverse orientation of the electric and magnetic fields
Section1.Para:
In the case of transverse effect the orientations of the magnetic fields (constant H 0 and alternating H with the frequency ω) will be perpendicular to the polarization vector P (which is directed along the Z axis). For transverse case in Eqs. (4) and (5), the variable m
H
k has to be replaced by the variable m
B
k . It is a more convenient form, because when we are substituting these equations into the equations of motion (1) we can use the fact that
$\frac{\partial B_{x}}{\partial x} = 0$ , since divB=0. For this case Eqs. (4) and (5) can be written in the following form: 20
$$\begin{aligned} &{{}^{m}S_{xx} = \frac{1}{{}^{m}Y^{B}}{}^{m}T_{xx} + {}^{m}g_{xx,x}{}^{m}B_{x},} \end{aligned}$$
21
$$\begin{aligned} &{{}^{m}B_{x} = {}^{m}q_{xx,x}{}^{m}T_{xx} + {}^{m}\mu_{xx}{}^{m}H_{x},} \end{aligned}$$ where
$\frac{1}{{}^{m}Y^{B}} = {}^{m}s_{xx}^{B}$ is the compliance of the piezomagnetic phase at constant magnetic induction and
${}^{m}g_{xx,x} = \frac{\partial {}^{m}S_{xx}}{\partial {}^{m}B_{x}}$ is the piezomagnetic coefficient. The coefficients
${}^{m}s_{xx}^{B}$ and m
g
xx,x are related to the coefficients m
s
xx and m
q
xx,x by the following form: 22
$$\begin{aligned} &{{}^{m}s_{xx}^{B} = {}^{m}s_{xx} - {}^{m}q_{xx,z} / {}^{m}\mu_{xx},} \end{aligned}$$
23
$$\begin{aligned} &{{}^{m}g_{xx,x} = \frac{{}^{m}q_{xx,x}}{{}^{m}\mu_{xx}}.} \end{aligned}$$

Calculations analogous to the case of longitudinal orientation of the fields gives the following expression for the transverse ME voltage coefficient: 24
$$\begin{aligned} \alpha_{E,T} =& \frac{{}^{p}Y{}^{p}d_{xx,z}{}^{m}g_{xx,x}}{{}^{p}\varepsilon_{zz}\varDelta _{T}}\frac{\mu \cdot {}^{m}Y^{B} \cdot {}^{m}t}{{}^{m}Y^{B} \cdot {}^{m}t\frac{th({}^{m}\kappa )}{{}^{m}\kappa} + {}^{p}Y{}^{p}t\frac{tg({}^{p}\kappa )}{{}^{p}\kappa}} \\ & {}\times \frac{tg(\kappa )}{\kappa} \frac{tg({}^{p}\kappa )}{{}^{p}\kappa} \frac{{}^{p}t}{({}^{m}t + {}^{p}t)}, \end{aligned}$$ where
$$\begin{aligned} \varDelta _{T} =& 1 - K_{p}^{2} \biggl( 1 - \frac{{}^{p}Y{}^{p}t}{{}^{m}Y^{B} \cdot {}^{m}t\frac{th({}^{m}\kappa )}{{}^{m}\kappa} + {}^{p}Y{}^{p}t\frac{tg({}^{p}\kappa )}{{}^{p}\kappa}} \\ &{}\times\frac{tg(\kappa )}{\kappa} \frac{tg({}^{p}\kappa )}{{}^{p}\kappa} \biggr), \end{aligned}$$ with μ the magnetic permeability.

As follows from Eqs. (19) and (24), the frequency dependence of the ME voltage coefficient has resonant character. At the so-called antiresonance frequencies when Δ
L =0 or Δ
T =0, there is a peak increase in the ME voltage coefficient. For the case of the small thickness, when the dimensionless parameters p
κ≪1 and m
κ≪1, we can use the fact that
$\frac{th({}^{m}\kappa )}{{}^{m}\kappa} \approx 1$ and
$\frac{tg({}^{p}\kappa )}{{}^{p}\kappa} \approx 1$ .
As can be seen, in this case Eqs. (19) and (24) transform into the equations obtained previously [6–9].

Section1.Heading: Experiment
Section1.Para: Experimental investigation of the effect was conducted for bilayer nickel–lead zirconate titanate (Ni-PZT) structure in the form of a rectangular plate. The samples of length 20 mm and width 4.3 mm were fabricated for the measurements. The thickness of the samples was ranging from 0.6 to 1.8 mm with constant nickel thickness of 0.29 mm and piezoceramics ranging from 0.3 to 1.5 mm. Before the measurements, the samples were polarized in an electric field of 4 kV/mm for three hours at a temperature of 80 °C. First, the field dependence of the low frequency ME voltage coefficient was studied at a fixed amplitude of the ac magnetic field of 1 Oe; the ME effect was measured as a function of the bias magnetic field. Then, for the bias magnetic field strength corresponding to the maximum ME coefficient, the frequency dependence of this coefficient was measured in the region of the electromechanical resonance. The open circuit condition in the measurement was satisfactory. The input impedance (active and capacitive resistance) of the preamplifier and contact wires exceeded the sample impedance more than tenfold.

The experimental results and theoretical dependence of resonance frequency on the thickness of the structure are presented in Fig. 2.
Fig. 2
Resonance frequency versus the thickness ratio of the layers in bilayer nickel–lead zirconate titanate (Ni-PZT) structure

The following parameters of the structure were used in the calculations: for nickel— m
Y=204 GPa, m
ρ=8900 kg/m3, m
q
xx,z =1156×10−12 m/A; and for the PZT: p
Y=65 GPa, p
ρ=7600 kg/m3, p
d
xx,z =−175×10−12 m/V, ε 33/ε 0=1750.

As can be seen from Fig. 2 the theoretical calculations are well consistent with the experimental results. Thus, the presented equations for ME voltage coefficient are more exact. They are true for both thin and thick layers.

Section1.Heading: Conclusion
Section1.Para: Layered magnetostrictive-piezoelectric structures demonstrate better ME properties than the bulk composites. It is shown that the consideration of nonuniformity along the direction perpendicular to the ferrite-piezoelectric interface leads to the nonlinear dispersion relation between the angular frequency and the wave vector which in the limiting case of small thickness transforms into a linear relationship.

The frequency dependence of the ME voltage coefficient has resonant character. The resonant frequency depends not only on the length of the sample but also on the thickness of magnetostrictive and piezoelectric layers.
